29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up
we are at the Sportfish Show in Berkshire.

34.text:
We have got all the regulars: News Stump,
Hunting YouTube and the experts from Skinners

40.text:
Petfoods for training a gun dog. First Roy
Lupton has found an unusual way of getting

49.text:
Roy is many things - but the one thing he
isn't is quick off the blocks. But there may

57.text:
Over the last few years on Fieldsports Britain,
I am sure the viewers have realised that I

62.text:
am little bit short, a little bit wobbly and
carry a few too many pounds, but thanks to

67.text:
the advancement in science that has been completely
blown out of the water and I am definitely

72.text:
now a little bit taller, a little bit faster
and damn sight smoother.

79.text:
Roy's been offered the chance of using the
off-road Segway-type machine by two visiting

86.text:
Dutch air rifle hunters who regularly charge
around the British countryside on these quiet

93.text:
Is my tongue poking out because that is the
thing which doesn't look good.

96.text:
For quarry. For Roy it's more important than
that - for the first time in a long time he's

101.text:
able to cover ground in relative comfort,
with stealth and at a decent pace. So, after

107.text:
a practice session, it's time to mount up
and steer the machine out into the field.

113.text:
All joking aside I have always wanted to have
a go on a Segway. I have always thought that

116.text:
there is a possibility to use them for stalking.
I mean they have got their limitations we

121.text:
are not going to be able to use them on the
hill in Scotland or whatever else, but stalking

124.text:
species like roe and muntjac I think for anybody
who has got a physical disability then any

132.text:
aid that you can use I think can only be a
good thing. So what I want to try today is

138.text:
to get around some of the little spinnys and
woods we have got here and try and see if

142.text:
we can call in any muntjac and it is really
to see whether we can stalk into position.

147.text:
I think though that to try and shoot off one
of these is going to be an impossibility so

150.text:
I am going to have to dismount before we take
the shot.

152.text:
Roy has always dreamed of having the wrong
trousers, Gromit, and now he has them. But

157.text:
will the machine really get us near deer?
It's certainly quiet and as long as the rides

162.text:
are clear we should have a pretty decent shot
at stalking in close. Then again...

177.text:
Despite teething problems we spot a muntjac
and Roy dismounts to sound the Buttolo call.

183.text:
We all but give up hope but then we realise
a buck has sneaked up behind us, so the call

188.text:
worked a treat. We just need eyes in the backs
of our heads.

191.text:
What a shame and typical. Really, really nice
buck, he is still kicking off there, and he

199.text:
snuck up right behind us. Not more than 15
yards behind us. He walked straight into us

205.text:
and made us. So he just kicked off and cleared
off and disappeared behind us. So that is

208.text:
a shame. He would have been absolutely perfect.
We have upset him.

220.text:
For a bit of fun we try and find this stroppy
buck.

231.text:
He is literally just behind the bush there
so he is 30, 40 yards away from us but we

242.text: just can't get an eye on him.

245.text:
Muntjac are feisty little deer. We let him
be. We've got ground to cover� and in style.

250.text:
Roy's new found freedom means cameraman David
is left lagging behind. This idea may not

257.text:
The next two calls deliver nowt, but we are
covering lots of ground.

262.text:
Then we get another sighting -it's brief,
but clearly the silver chariot is not affecting

267.text:
We bomb around the ground squeaking here and
there. With poor weather and light levels

272.text:
falling, it is not to be� but what a fun
couple of hours we've had.

275.text:
I suppose the big question is when I actually
go out and buy one of these and I think after

280.text:
the amount of fun I have had this afternoon
the answer is most definitely yes. The only

286.text:
down side is that I am enjoying the speed
too much so I am trying to get to places a

290.text:
lot quicker than I would walk because I tend
to be a little bit slower than most other

295.text:
people and I tend to find that by being slow
it gives you more chance to use your binoculars,

301.text:
to glass and to see more. Whereas today I
did actually bump a few deer because I was

305.text:
getting carried away with it. If I could learn
to ride it a little bit slower it might work

308.text:
but at the moment, I have got to be honest,
I am just enjoying the speed.

313.text: What a buzz - well, actually more of a hum.

316.text:
From Roy to someone else who is fast on his
feet, it is David on the Fieldsports Channel

332.text:
A German angler fishing off the coast of Norway
has caught what is expected to be a new world

336.text:
record breaking cod. Michael Eisele has donated
the 103lb cod, which would provide 200 fish

344.text:
suppers, to the Norwegian Fisheries Museum
in Bergen. The previous world record of 98lbs

350.text:
12oz was caught off New Hampshire in the United
States in 1969.

356.text:
Adam Cork has won the English Open Sporting
Champion. Held at Doveridge Clay Sports Centre

361.text:
in Derbyshire, Adam scored 91 ex 100. We caught
up with Richard Faulds half way through the

367.text:
The first couple of rotations of shot, it
is a tough shoot there are a lot of targets

372.text:
under a lot of power, but just the degree
of difficulty is, I would have said above

379.text:
If you fancy some country fun this month the
Burghley Game and Country Fair is on May 26th

384.text:
and 27th. Set in the grounds of one of the
UK's most beautiful stately home the Fair

389.text:
offers three arenas full of displays from
fishing to falconry. You can try your hand

394.text:
at air gunning, artery, paint balling and
dog handling. There is also a food glorious

398.text:
food show. So plenty of excuses to eat, drink
and be merry over the late bank holiday weekend.

404.text:
Fancy buying a gun company? US-based ammo
and munitions maker ATK has just paid US$315

410.text:
million - more than �200 million - for Caliber
Co, the parent company of Savage Sports. ATK

417.text:
also owns Federal Premium, CCI, Fusion, and
Speer.

422.text:
The Association of Air Ambulances has written
to thank foxhunters and staghunters. Some

428.text:
28 packs raised more than �32,000 for air
ambulance services across the UK last season.

436.text:
And finally, and sticking with charity the
World Pheasant Association raised more than

440.text:
�12,000 at a charity clay pigeon shoot in
Berkshire, which will help fund research it

445.text:
does into black grouse. It is holding another
shoot in Oxfordshire on Friday 21st June.

455.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

465.text:
Thank you David, could be time for a hair
cut. Now let's go to Hallo Charlie.

475.text: Here's what the world's up to this week.

479.text:
Hallo Charlie, it is me the Crew Hunter. You
may remember me from my amazing crow calling

485.text:
video. Anyhow we are out here today in sunny
Ireland and I am shooting some feral pigeons

491.text: and crows. So chow for now.

494.text:
Hallo Charlie, it is Andrew from the 85K Eleven
YouTube Channel on the vermin hunting forum.

500.text:
This morning I am in some stables shooting
some piegeons.

503.text: Look into the camera ... say it.

510.text: Is it? Your name is Charlie.

514.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie - film yourself
on your mobile phone - just a sentence saying

517.text:
hallo Charlie, who you are and what you're
up to. Then share it or email it via YouTube,

522.text:
Facebook, DropBox or YouSendIt, you name it
to charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

526.text:
Now to something which may have an effect
on the great lead shot debate. I have been

531.text: to a seedy hotel in Manchester.

534.text:
So my story starts in the grubby suburb of
Manchester called Salford, partly because

538.text:
it is an industrial parkland where they used
to pump heavy metals into the water and partly

543.text:
because the BBC is based here so you won't
find any shooters.

546.text:
Now an Australian company called Andalyze
has sent me this dodgy looking suitcase with

554.text:
a tester for lead and other heavy metals in
water, perfect for shooters. Let's see how

559.text:
Manchester tap water fairs. This is Manchester
tap water. Fast forward to five minutes later

565.text: and there you have it below 1ppb.

569.text:
Now we have spent a happy week zooming around
the UK as per usual and we have been collecting

577.text:
water along the way. Here's me getting it
from Doveridge clayground, where the pond

582.text:
must surely be full of lead shot thanks to
evil clayshooters, the lake next to Sportfish

589.text:
in Reading where those wicked anglers have
been chucking even more lead, and even the

595.text:
Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust at Slimbridge in
Gloucestershire, which is committed to banning

599.text:
lead shot. So surely it is cleaner than clean.
Let's test these samples.

604.text:
Now of course this has got nothing to do with
ducks ingesting lead shot because they have

610.text:
got no teeth, but the antis are trying to
accuse shooters of poisoning the environment

615.text: and the water supply with lead as well.

619.text: Conclusive proof that the water is safe.

624.text:
I ask shooter and deer farmer Mike Dickinson:
what is the politics of lead?

628.text:
There is all sorts. There are people who ban
lead for various reasons. Some with their

635.text:
own agendas but there is no evidence for what
they are trying to say.

641.text:
Now is that because they don't like lead or
is it because they don't like shooting.

644.text:
Both. Both. May be because they don't like
shooting.

650.text:
For more about the ANDalyze handheld water
tester, go to ANDalyze.com

655.text:
Flapping flags and flying canvas we might
be at a country show. Well we are. It is the

662.text:
Sportfish Show in Berkshire and this year
the theme is technology.

666.text:
If you yearn to go back to a simpler age,
where you dangle a pin on a strand of horsehair

673.text:
tied to a willow wand you have cut from yonder
copse, forget it. Today's angler can reach

694.text:
the parts that others have only dreamed of,
thanks to new rods, new reels and even an

698.text:
innovative method of mending waders. Somewhere,
deep in the heart of the Sportfish open weekend,

707.text:
Things do wear out. Lots of things while you
are fishing. Could be a barbed wire fence,

712.text:
could be thorns or things like that, or general
wear. Obviously these are gortex, with a gortex

718.text:
membrane in them and what we have done today,
part of the whole thing with Simms gear is

723.text:
that they can easily be repaired. Tom is our
repair expert here from Oslo. So we have a

728.text:
little demonstration where we use something
called isopropyl alcohol which does a little

734.text:
bit of magic and it shows up any pinholes
in the waders. It is really quite clever.

738.text:
If you have any punctures it will show up
a little black spot. It is so easy to find

746.text:
So you can just use a bit of aquaseal and
repair the waders very easily.

751.text:
While the Sportfish shop is getting the bite
into customers, cramming into it, admiring

756.text:
and buying tackle, on the grass outside is
a large marquee stuffed with the great and

761.text:
the good from the angling industry, showing
off products old fashioned and new-fangled.

767.text:
This is where to find out what's catching
the eye of the modern fisherman.

772.text:
A lot of this need for technology comes down
to where we are fishing - and some of that

775.text: is the fault of agencies such as Frontiers.

777.text:
Frontiers has been around since 1969 and we
invented the idea of fishing travel. When

784.text:
we started with the exception of a little
bit of salmon fishing abroad, which Russia

791.text:
was beginning to create, it was a new thing
to do. That is what is called a GT, Giant

799.text:
Trevally. You catch it in the Seychelles most
famously, but other places as well. That is

805.text:
a sea trout from Rio Grande ... Fuego. The
green and yellow fish down the bottom is a

818.text:
There is a good showing from one of the UK's
foremost tackle companies, Hardy Greys, based

823.text:
in the North-East. Howard Croston, head of
product development, is bringing a new range

828.text:
of technology to ignorant southerners like
me.

830.text:
We produce fishing equipment which you can
use basically all globe. We do everything

836.text:
from big game fly fishing equipment. Right
through course fishing, carp fishing, sea

841.text:
fishing. Technology is very much part of our
business. Heritage is also a very big part.

849.text:
Still manufacturing cane rods right from the
start. At the other end of the scale we are

850.text:
working with very advanced nano loaded resins
and new fibre types. So really it is one of

857.text:
those things it is really a quirky company,
we have got the history of being one of the

863.text:
oldest fishing tacklers of the world, yet
we are right on the cutting edge of modern

868.text:
The flytying here has a modern twist and if
you are watching this on Youtube you can click

871.text:
on these films to see them in full. The mayfly
hatch on southern English chalkstreams is

876.text:
worryingly late this year, so Chris Reeves
of FishingClass.co.uk is tying an all-purpose

883.text:
nymph on the Parkridge of Redditch stand.
Meanwhile, for those who have given up on

887.text:
freshwater altogether, Jo Stephenson on the
UKBass.com stand is tying an all-purpose fry

895.text:
Also at the show is one of the biggest names
in flyfishing, Charles Jardine, who seems

900.text:
to be confusing himself with his distant cousin
Douglas. It might be May but it's not perfect

905.text: weather for either flyfishing or cricket.

907.text: It is jolly cold in here.

910.text:
I would love a hanky. I just haven't made
a hanky to go with this. Basically the idea

916.text:
Charlie was to get a bunch of fly lines. I
did exactly what they said on the tin to dispel

926.text:
myth. To give people coming into the sport
especially a degree of confidence and also

933.text:
a line that is eminently fishable. There is
one over there which was just under that was

939.text:
the line of choice of the fishers at Grafham
because it met exactly the requirements at

945.text:
the back end of last year. If you are talking
about bass fishing, or fishing for Pollack,

950.text:
gold fish or anything really that swims in
the sea that we can fish with a fly, because

955.text:
that is, I was going to say battle ground,
which it is sometimes, but that is a new era

961.text:
for us, a new way of looking at the sport.
Taking it out of the confines of just purely,

970.text:
what we would expect, trout fishing on rivers
and reservoirs and saying look you can do

973.text:
this. Go on holiday go mackerel fishing, bass
fishing. Here is a nice little line to take

980.text:
Fishing tackle design has taken a leap forward
in the last few years. People are taking their

985.text:
rods to new heights, which is why manufacturers
have been to talk to the aerospace industry.

990.text:
Carbon fibre technology is not developed for
the fishing rods it is developed for the aerospace

994.text:
industry and the airbus which you will know
about. There are 300 odd airbuses being made

1000.text:
in the world at the minute. That is what the
materialist develops to be lighter and stronger

1004.text:
and the fishing rod industry rides piggy back
on the back of that, but the range of materials

1011.text:
now that are available for making fishing
rods is huge. So the skill is a marriage of

1017.text:
art and science, the skill is knowing which
types of carbon fibre materials to match up.

1023.text:
Because you don't have just one type in a
rod, you might have three or four different

1026.text:
types positioned in different places down
the blank.

1030.text:
Another US rod manufacturer, Sage, is based
in the same town as aircraft manufacturer

1036.text:
We get a lot of research out of Boeing. They
bring it to us we bring a little to them and

1042.text:
we have a great relationship with a number
of the engineers who are fishermen. They love

1046.text:
to come over for the little break it gives
them and we have a great time with Boeing.

1051.text:
It is very important because they are one
of the leaders in aerospace and that is where

1055.text:
all the great material comes from. We are
always interested in making goods lighter

1059.text:
and stronger and literally what they are doing
with the new 7/87 Airliner is really in this

1067.text:
rod to a degree. So it really works out pretty
nicely for us.

1071.text:
Sportfish has run this show over a May weekend
every year for a dozen years.

1076.text: It is a long time, a long time.

1079.text:
But it is what our customers expect of us
now and we love putting it on. It is great.

1084.text:
Entry is free, parking is free. We have got
guys coming from all over the world. Got guys

1090.text:
from the United States, Scandinavia and even
Scotland. Exotic locations like that.

1096.text:
All the retailers in there are showing their
new products and all the new exciting things

1101.text:
they have brought with them and it is a great
opportunity for our customers to have a look

1104.text:
at those and come back and give us the feed
back of what they have seen and really like

1108.text:
and that gives us a good head start on a bit
later in the year to bring in those products

1114.text:
Really importantly because it is showcase
for that technology people can see the rods,

1122.text:
but the experts from the companies that have
designed them will chat to you and they will

1126.text:
go out and cast the rods with you on the water.
So you hear the full story of the rod's development

1134.text:
and actually see the guy who has designed
it casting it which I think is amazing.

1138.text:
Absolutely wonderful. So you have got all
this kit, all this technology and all these

1143.text:
people here. How many fish have you caught
today?

1145.text:
Ah, one. Actually fishing has been hard today.
This is a great fishery so I don't know the

1149.text:
answer to that. But it is cold for the fish
as the same as it is for us. You know we have

1154.text:
had a run up, the last few days there have
been big flocks of swallows over the lake

1160.text:
and they have been eating buzzers which have
been hatching and that is not going on today.

1163.text:
They are not playing. So it is not a fishing
day, but a great day for a show.

1168.text:
A brilliant day for a show. Now to the wider
world of hunting, shooting and fishing on

1180.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1185.text:
Now I am not a fan of kill shot compilations.
However, Last deer hunting season highlights

1190.text:
by GregLoginWay is a good one, just uploaded,
with highlights from 2012.

1195.text:
Continuing the roebuck theme, Sercout calls
himself Roe Buck King of Denmark in this film.

1200.text:
It is a good beast no question, and you can
decide for yourself whether to call Sercout

1204.text:
Now, not exactly a shooting video and it's
been around for two years but something to

1208.text:
chew on as the clay pigeon season gets underway.
Golfers from the European Tour get together

1212.text:
in Dubai to see f they can break a clay with
a golf ball. Can they do it? Course they can.

1217.text:
And people say that that guy is still running
today.

1220.text:
Moving to fishing and we are in San Francisco
Bay in northern California where they catch

1224.text:
sturgeon on rod and line. It's a bit of a
promo, because HelpUFish is a fishing guide

1229.text: too, but, hey, it's sturgeon and it's California.

1232.text:
Salmon Fishing Ireland 2013 - The Dam Fishery
is a straightforward film about pulling a

1237.text:
biggish head-and-tailing fish out of an Irish
river. The information is interesting - but

1242.text:
the commentary is a bit of a waste of a good
Irish accent.

1244.text:
Back to hunting and it's driven wild boar
on a GoPro - what those little cameras were

1248.text:
I reckon designed for. MrFrenchhunter is having
bonne temps on a driven hunt.

1253.text:
There are some good antelope hunting videos
coming out of South Africa at the moment.

1256.text:
I have picked Impala hunting in Eastern Cape,
which may be a bit wobbly compared to some

1262.text:
Finally, the snow goose hunting season is
underway in snowy South Dakota. Golfmann96's

1267.text:
buddy went there for a four-day hunting trip
and he was along to film.

1270.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1273.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1280.text:
Now a speedy top tip from the Skinners Petfoods
expert how to improve your gundog.

1295.text:
Small gundogs like cocker spaniels? How can
they be suitable for big wildfowl like geese.

1301.text:
Well, with a top gundog trainer like Howard
Kirby on hand, here's how.

1304.text:
Everything is progression. It is what we call
layer training, so when we start we start

1308.text:
with maybe a tennis ball or a tiny puppy dummy.
You can use an ordinary dummy, that is quite

1313.text:
a big dummy to use on an intermediate dog.
We have then got this fluffy rabbit ball that

1318.text:
helps to start the transition it is still
small, it rolls so it excites the dog. Sometimes

1323.text:
the dog will get completely fed up with a
tennis ball so if you bring one of these out

1327.text:
with a bit of fluff on it, you spit on it
or you rub it in some cold game. You make

1332.text:
it smell of a pigeon, a rabbit it is a great
way to make the transition from a plain old

1336.text:
dummy which is just a bag of shavings or a
tennis ball which is rubber with fluff on

1341.text:
it towards slowly building them up to live
game. And that is a layered up process. We

1345.text:
don't rush them straight out and show them
a pheasant because things can go very wrong

1350.text:
and you can spoil your gun dog by rushing
them into cold or hot game.

1353.text:
And with heavier game what do you do? Tie
two pigeons together?

1358.text:
No, I have never tied two pigeons together,
but you could. You just create more weight

1364.text:
gradually. Classically a small pigeon, a partridge
and then a hen pheasant, then cock pheasant

1371.text:
and finally you move up to hares and geese
and stuff like that if you think your dog

1375.text:
is likely to encounter that in the shooting
field. It will at some point. So it is a gradual

1379.text:
process. Certainly you wouldn't expect a little
14 week old puppy to try and pick up a hen.

1384.text:
He is not going to do it. It is just plain
silly.

1386.text:
Howard runs Mullenscote Gundogs from Lains
Shooting School near Andover in Hampshire.

1390.text:
Visit Mullenscote.co.uk. This series on gundog
training tips is brought to you by Skinners

1395.text:
Petfoods, maker of the Field & Trial range
of gundog feeds. Visit SkinnersPetfoods.co.uk

1403.text:
Before we go, the Schools Challenge Bredon
weekend has just been and gone! The second

1409.text:
leg of the Schools Challenge takes place at
Bredon School in Gloucestershire, with dozens

1413.text:
of schools and hundreds of kids taking part.
Watch the highlights in this week's episode

1419.text:
of Schools Challenge TV. Click on the link
on the screen to see the film.

1424.text:
Well we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube please hit the subscribe

1428.text:
button that is somewhere around the outside
of the screen or go to our website www.fieldsportschannel.tv

1431.text:
where you can click to like us on Facebook,
follow us on Twitter or pop your email address

1435.text:
into the constant contact form and we will
be in touch with you every week about our

1439.text:
show which is out 7pm UK time on Wednesdays.
This has been Fieldsports Britain.
